Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.2: PROPERTY OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique identifier assigned to each propertymeasurement observation
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: AVERAGE MUD PROPERTY VALUE: The numeric value of the mud property wherea single value is recorded or if an average is calculated.
Column Comment.5: MUD PROPERTY OUOM: original unit of measure.
Column Comment.6: MUD PROPERTY VALUE UNIT OF MEASURE
Column Comment.7: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format columns, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.8: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.9: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.10: MAXIMUM VALUE: The highest value measured for this property.
Column Comment.13: MINIMUM VALUE: the lowest value measured for this property.
Column Comment.16: MUD ANALYSIS OBSERVATION NUMBER: A Unique observation number for themud analysis.
Column Comment.17: MUD PROPERTY TYPE: The type of mud property being measured, such asalkalinity. Various properties may be measured using numbers, codes or textualdescriptions.
Column Comment.18: MUD PROPERTY CODE: A validated code for the property being measured, in thecase where the response is selected from a list of allowed values. In each case, thecodes allowed are specific to the property type being measured.
Column Comment.19: MUD PROPERTY DESCRIPTION: Textual description of the mud property in thecase where validated text values and numbers are not appropriate.
Column Comment.20: MUD PROPERTY REFERENCE TYPE: The type of mud property reference thatqualifies a mud property measurement, such as temperature.
Column Comment.21: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.22: REFERENCE VALUE: The value of a reference value, such as temperature orpressure, at which the reading is taken.
Column Comment.25: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.26: SAMPLE TYPE: Type of sample being measured (e.g., mud, mud cake or filtrate).
Column Comment.27: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.28: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample.
Column Comment.29: UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: A unique name, code or number designated as theprimary key for this row.
Column Comment.30: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.31: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.32: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.33: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.34: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.35: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.36: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
